Link Shortening Platforms are online platforms which allow people to create Accounts that they can use to convert existing URLs into Shortened Links, or into QR Codes.

objects.name: Shortened Link Asset
objects.description: A Shortened Link is a custom URL which is typically a shortened version of another URL.

objects.name: QR Code Asset
objects.description: A QR Code allows people to use cameras on their smartphones to open a URL.

objects.name: Online Advertising Platform
objects.description:
Google Ads, Facebook Ads, and LinkedIn Marketing Solutions are examples of Online Advertising Platforms.

Online Advertising Platforms are online platforms which allow people to create Accounts that they can use to upload and deliver adverts to people online.

objects.name: Content Recommendation Algorithm
objects.description: Many online platforms have Content Recommendation Algorithms, which promote content posted to the platform to users based on metrics the platform operators are trying to meet. Algorithms typically surface platform content which the user is likely to engage with, based on how they and other users have behaved on the platform.

objects.name: Direct Messaging
objects.description:
Many online platforms allow users to contact other platform users via Direct Messaging; private messaging which can be initiated by a user with other platform users.

Examples include messaging on WhatsApp, Telegram, and Signal; direct messages (DMs) on Facebook or Instagram.

Some platforms’ Direct Messaging capabilities provide users with Encrypted Communication.

objects.name: Digital Content Creation Asset
objects.description: Digital Content Creation Assets are Platforms or Software which help actors produce content for publication online.

objects.name: AI LLM Platform
objects.description:
OpenAI’s ChatGPT, Google’s Bard, Microsoft’s Turing-NLG, Google’s T5 (Text-to-Text Transfer Transformer), and Facebook’s BART are examples of AI LLM (Large Language Model) Platforms.

AI LLM Platforms are online platforms which allow people to create Accounts that they can use to interact with the platform’s AI Large Language Model, to produce text-based content.

LLMs can create hyper-realistic synthetic text that is both scalable and persuasive. LLMs can largely automate content production, reducing the overhead in persona creation, and generate culturally appropriate outputs that are less prone to exhibiting conspicuous signs of inauthenticity.

Some platforms implement protections against misuse of AI by their users. Threat Actors have been observed bypassing these protections using prompt injections, poisoning, jailbreaking, or integrity attacks.

objects.name: AI Media Platform
objects.description:
AI Media Platforms are online platforms that allow people to create Accounts which they can use to produce image, video, or audio content (also known as “deepfakes”) using the platform’s AI Software.

Midjourney, DALL-E, Stable Diffusion, and Adobe Firefly are examples of AI Media Platforms which allow users to Develop AI-Generated Images, Videos and Account Imagery.

Similarly, Reface, Zao, FaceApp, and Wombo are mobile apps which offer features for creating AI-Generated videos, gifs, or trending memes.

AI-Generated Audio such as text-to-speech and voice cloning have revolutionised the creation of synthetic voices that closely mimic human speech. AI Media Platforms such as Descript, Fliki, Murf AI, PlayHT, and Resemble AI can be used to generate synthetic voice.

Some platforms implement protections against misuse of AI by their users. Threat Actors have been observed bypassing these protections using prompt injections, poisoning, jailbreaking, or integrity attacks.

objects.name: Gated Asset
objects.description: Some assets are Gated; closed communities or platforms which can’t be accessed openly. They may be password protected or require admin approval for entry. Many different digital assets can be gated. This technique contains sub-techniques with methods used to gate assets. Analysts can use T0155: Gated Asset if the method of gating is unclear.

objects.name: Password Gated Asset
objects.description:
A Password Gated Asset is an online asset which requires a password to gain access.

Examples include password protected Servers set up to be a File Hosting Platform, or password protected Community Sub-Forums.

objects.name: Invite Gated Asset
objects.description:
An Invite Gated Asset is an online asset which requires an existing user to invite other users for access to the asset.

Examples include Chat Groups in which Administrator Accounts are able to add or remove users, or File Hosting Platforms which allow users to invite other users to access their files.

objects.name: Approval Gated Asset
objects.description:
An Approval Gated Asset is an online asset which requires approval from Administrator Accounts for access to the asset.

Examples include Online Community Groups on Facebook, which can be configured to require questions and approval before access, and Accounts on Social Media Platforms such as Instagram, which allow users to set their accounts as visible to approved friends only.

objects.name: Geoblocked Asset
objects.description:
A Geoblocked Asset is an online asset which cannot be accessed in specific geographical locations.

Assets can be Geoblocked by choice of the platform, or can have Geoblocking mandated by regulators, and enforced through Internet Service Providers.

objects.name: Paid Access Asset
objects.description: A Paid Access Asset is an online asset which requires a single payment for permanent access to the asset.

objects.name: Subscription Access Asset
objects.description:
A Subscription Access Asset is an online asset which requires a continued subscription for access to the asset.

Examples include the Blogging Platform Substack, which affords Blogs hosted on their platform the ability to produce subscriber-only posts, and the Subscription Service Platform Patreon.

objects.name: Encrypted Communication Channel
objects.description: Some online platforms support encrypted communication between platform users, for example the Chat Platforms Telegram and Signal.

objects.name: Content Verifiability
objects.description: This Technique contains Sub-Techniques which allow analysts to identify whether a piece of content can be independently corroborated using trustworthy, external information sources. Verifiability is central to evaluating credibility, as verifiable claims can be confirmed or refuted through evidence-based assessment.

objects.name: Information is Verified
objects.description:
This sub-technique applies when content has been fact-checked and validated against reliable sources or evidence. This indicates high confidence in the accuracy of an actor’s claim.

Indicators include confirmation by multiple independent outlets, corroboration by experts, or data-supported validation.

objects.name: Information is False
objects.description:
This sub-technique applies when information has been demonstrated to be factually incorrect. False information may stem from intentional deception, misinterpretation, or outdated data.

Indicators include refutation by multiple authoritative experts or visible contradiction by primary source evidence.

objects.name: Information is Unverifiable
objects.description:
This sub-technique applies when content cannot be verified because the data, witnesses, or evidence are unavailable, unreliable, or inaccessible. This often occurs in emerging events or contexts with unclear information like conflict or disaster zones.

Indicators include missing source data, anonymous claims, or unverifiable eyewitness accounts. Additionally it can be a case where something is impossible to prove given the limits of current information gathering.

objects.name: Information is Misleading
objects.description:
Information presented by the actor contains some accurate or verifiable information, but is presented in a misleading way, potentially leading people to an incorrect conclusion.

Indicators include cherry-picking / selective disclosure of information, quoting out of context, ambiguous or vague sourcing, mixing fact and speculation without labeling, loaded language or rhetorical framing.

objects.name: Content Produced as Satire
objects.description:
Satirical content often mimics real events or personas for comedic or critical effect. While not intended to deceive, satire can be mistaken for factual reporting when shared without context.

Indicators include hyperbole, comedic tone, or origin from known satire outlets. Fact-checkers often verify such content as false but satirical.

objects.name: Content Previously Fact Checked
objects.description:
There are times where content which has previously been addressed by Fact Checkers goes viral again - particularly the case with highly emotive, or striking content which resonates with viewers. This highlights platforms’ failure to use available work by Fact Checkers to minimise the propagation of information disorder.

To make this assessment, analysts need to identify reporting which addresses a claim or piece of content, and confirm that this reporting discussed a previous iteration of it appearing online.

objects.name: Claim Previously Fact Checked
objects.description:
A piece of content makes a claim which has previously been addressed by Fact Checkers. Fact Checkers have observed the same claims going viral in cycles, necessitating repeated work in debunking them.

Some misleading or false claims have inherent virality; they may be salacious, shocking, attention grabbing, or seem intuitively accurate (where the truth is boring and complicated). Fact Checkers have noted that some claims go viral on a cyclical basis, and have to repeatedly address the same claims.

This Sub-Technique can be used to note that a claim has been published which has previously been addressed by Fact Checkers.

objects.name: Falsified Content
objects.description:
Material published by an actor has been falsified or fabricated.

To make this assertion, analysts need to confirm that published material has been created inorganically.

This Technique contains Sub-techniques with specific types of falsified content.

objects.name: Impersonated Content
objects.description:
Content has been designed to look like it was made by another individual or institution. This has the outcome of narratives benefiting from targets’ existing faith in the impersonated entity, negatively impacting people’s faith in future content they see attributed to the impersonated entity, and tying up the impersonated entity’s resources by forcing them to spend time and effort debunking the claims attributed to them.

Common examples of impersonated content include video news reports (e.g. falsified short-form videos designed to look like they were produced by news outlets), news articles (e.g. screenshots or photographs of falsified news articles designed to look like they were published by news outlets), and documents (e.g. falsified statements designed to look like they were produced by government institutions).

Impersonated content covers direct impersonations (e.g. the use of a brand’s logo on content not produced by them), and implicit impersonations (e.g. the use of a brand’s typeface, colour scheme, formatting and style, but not naming them or using their logos).

To make this assertion, analysts may check official sources for the organisation which purportedly published the material, and look for content which was published at the date or time which the potential impersonation was published to see if it appeared on official channels. They may ask representatives from outlets to confirm whether the potential impersonation was produced by them.

They may check for inconsistencies in how content was produced (e.g. differing fonts, placement of logos, language used, use of music). They may also look for the source of materials used in the potential impersonation, which often take advantage of stock media, or splicing together footage from a variety of sources.

objects.name: Statement Incorrectly Presented as Made by Individual or Institution
objects.description:
A statement has incorrectly been presented as having been made by an individual or institution.

Misattributed statements come in many forms. For example, entirely falsified videos or articles can include misattributed statements, an image of a person can be posted alongside a statement which they didn’t actually make, or it can be something as simple as a post claiming a statement was made by an individual or institution.

To make this assertion, analysts may search for reports from official sources supporting the claim that that the individual or institution has made the statement attributed to them. They may check the veracity of the attribution with the individual or institution themselves, or entities associated with them. If the statement was claimed to have been made online (e.g. in a post to social media), they may check for posts published on the date it was claimed the statement was made (including online tools which archive since-deleted posts).

objects.name: Falsified Graffiti or Signage
objects.description:
Threat actors have been observed editing media depicting locations in targeted countries to impose materials that imply locals are protesting against a cause ((e.g. falsified graffiti protesting continued support for Ukraine resisting Russia’s 2022 full-scale invasion)[https://www.sgdsn.gouv.fr/files/files/20240611_NP_SGDSN_VIGINUM_Matriochka_EN_VF.pdf]) or that authorities are taking a stance ((e.g. falsified government billboard ads rallying locals against Ukraine)[https://www.stopfake.org/en/strong-photofake-anti-ukrainian-billboards-appear-in-poland-strong/]) which are beneficial to the threat actor’s narrative.

To make this assertion, analysts may review images or video for digital artifacts indicative of edited media. They may look for source media which directly match the edited content without the presence of the purported graffiti or signage. They may check for the existence of footage depicting the purported graffiti or signage from other angles.

objects.name: Imagery Depicting Individual Edited to Introduce Sexual Material
objects.description:
Threat Actors have been observed harassing individuals by producing edits of them which introduce their visage to sexual content. This can have the impact of harming their reputation, or inducing feelings of shame or fear, and in some cases can risk physical violence against the target. While this technique can be used to target anyone, it is often levelled at women.

This Sub-Technique covers cases where images or videos depicting individuals are spliced into sexual media, or images or videos depicting them are edited to introduce sexual elements.

To make this assertion, analysts may identify the source imagery of the targeted individual (i.e. which media their visage was taken from) and confirm it didn’t originally contain sexually explicit content. They may also look for editing artefacts (e.g. mismatched lighting, poor cropping or blurring, or unnatural angles where the visage has been introduced to the sexual scene).

objects.name: Reframe Context
objects.description: Reframing context involves presenting material in such a way that its meaning or implications change. This may include removing, reordering, or mislabeling contextual details (such as time, location, source, or origin) so that audiences draw inaccurate conclusions.

objects.name: Incorrect Subtitled Speech Reframes Context
objects.description:
Subtitles added to content to support viewers in understanding what was said by an individual can misrepresent what was said, which is difficult for viewers to detect when watching a speaker of another language, or videos without an audio track.

To make this assertion, analysts need to confirm that what was said was meaningfully different to the subtitles provided for the speech (i.e. not nit-picking minor translation issues, but changes which make changes to the context of what was said).

Analysts may require bilingual speakers to identify mistranslations. They can also search for the original media to search for original subtitles.

objects.name: Edits Made to News Report which Reframe Context
objects.description:
Actors have been observed making edits to news reports to change what was reported (including video and audio broadcasts by news outlets, or screenshots of articles published to news websites). This has the impact of borrowing a news outlet’s credibility to promote a narrative, but also to increase mistrust of future material legitimately published by the news outlet as another potential edit.

To make this assertion, analysts need to identify the original broadcast, or to identify elements which have been introduced via editing which are inconsistent with content legitimately published by the news outlet (e.g. incorrect location of the outlet’s logo, a new typeface, or inconsistently sized font).

objects.name: Historic Content Incorrectly Presented as Current
objects.description:
Video and Image content published or created in the past may be reshared and misrepresented as showing current events. For example, footage depicting previous armed conflicts have been reshared as depicting current conflicts.

To make this assertion, analysts need to identify the original source which a piece of content has come from, and confirm that it was published or created on a different date or time than it is being presented as depicting.

Indicators include discrepancies in timestamps or meta data, visible environmental or contextual clues (such as weather, attire, or signage), the absence of current corroborating reports, or analysts using tools such as reverse image search providers to identify previous publications of content.

objects.name: Content Incorrectly Presented as Depicting Another Location
objects.description:
Video and Image content depicting a specific location may be misrepresented as depicting another location. For example, a video showing a protest in one country may be presented as showing a protest in another country.

To make this assertion, analysts need to identify the location depicted in a piece of content (e.g. through geolocation), and confirm that it is incorrectly being presented as depicting another location.

Indicators include visible indicators of separate geography like different language, climate, topography or architecture.

objects.name: Video Game Content Incorrectly Presented as Depicting Reality
objects.description:
Modern game visuals or cutscenes can be realistic enough to be mistaken for genuine imagery, particularly footage depicting fast-moving or chaotic scenes (such as combat). For example, fact checkers have addressed claims where footage taken from games centred on armed warfare (e.g. Arma 3, Digital Combat Simulator World) being presented as footage of current conflicts.

To make this assertion, analysts need to confirm that the original source for a piece of content was a video game, and that the content was presented as showing real life (e.g. posted alongside text which treats or reacts to the content as legitimate).

Indicators include frame rate artifacts, unnatural physics, or gaming interface remnants.

objects.name: AI-Generated Content Incorrectly Presented as Depicting Reality
objects.description:
Synthetic content created using generative AI tools (e.g., deepfakes, AI image, video, or audio) is incorrectly presented as a depiction of real-world material; i.e. captured by a camera, a recording device, or otherwise manually produced by a human without the use of AI.

To make this assertion, analysts need to identify that content shared has been AI-Generated, and that it was presented in the context of the media showing real life (e.g. posted alongside text which treats or reacts to the content as legitimate).

As AI continues to develop capability to produce more realistic media, it is difficult to provide a list of methods to spot materials that have been created using AI which will not rapidly become outdated; platforms providing AI media generation are attempting to make the materials they produce indistinguishable from media made by humans.

At the same time, organisations create tools designed to help identify AI-generated content, and publish resources listing the latest tells and identifiers for AI-generated content. Analysts may look for such tools or resources to help identify the use of AI.

objects.name: Context Reframed by Edits to Media
objects.description:
Media which has been edited through cropping (zooming in from a larger image), clipping (taking a short section from a longer piece of content), or otherwise making changes to content in such a way that its meaning is changed, or that it can support a new incorrect or misleading interpretation of events.

To make this assertion, analysts need to identify the original source which a piece of content has come from, and confirm that the content has been edited in such a way that the context of the original media is lost or changed.

Indicators include abrupt transitions, mismatched lighting or shadows, or inconsistencies between visual and audio elements.

objects.name: Statement Reframed by Removal from Context
objects.description:
A statement legitimately made by an individual or institution has been taken out of its original context which reframes its meaning (sometimes referred to as “Quote Mining”).

For example, an individual may have been performing a speech in which they were quoting a statement made by a political opponent. By editing out the context that they were quoting an opponent, the speaker can be made to look like they were making the statement themselves.

To make this assertion, analysts need to identify the original source of a statement (e.g. written argument, video interview, podcast, etc), and confirm that in its original context it has a different meaning, or interpretation.

objects.name: Entertainment Media Content Incorrectly Presented as Depicting Reality
objects.description:
Entertainment media, including films, TV shows, or other staged performances uploaded to the internet are occasionally misrepresented as genuine real-world footage.

To make this assertion, analysts need to confirm that the original source for a piece of content was a piece of entertainment media (e.g. a clip from a TV show, movie, or staged media published to YouTube, including behind-the-scenes footage), and that it was presented in the context of the media showing real life (e.g. posted alongside text which treats or reacts to the content as legitimate).

Indicators include cinematic framing, production-level lighting, or identifiable actors/ known pieces of entertainment.

objects.name: Content Originally Produced as Satire Presented as Not Satire
objects.description:
Satirical or parody content stripped of its humorous framing and redistributed as genuine, factual information, can mislead audiences, particularly when it aligns with existing beliefs.

To make this assertion, analysts need to identify the original source for a piece of content, and confirm that it was originally framed as satire (e.g. posts which are tagged or disclaimed as satire), or published by an individual or organisation claiming to be satirical (e.g. satirical news outlets), and that it is now being presented as not satirical content.

Indicators include exaggerated claims, comedic tone, or association with known satire outlets.

objects.name: Issues with Cited Academic Research
objects.description:
A narrative makes a claim, and points to academic research to back up the legitimacy of the claim - however, the research has issues which make it an unreliable source.

This Technique contains Sub-Techniques which identify specific issues with cited academic research.

To count as a citation, the content must explicitly point to a specific piece of academic research to support a claim. This could be via an embedded link, footnotes, or providing the name of a paper, the journal it appears in, and the researchers who produced it.

objects.name: Narrative Cites Nonexistent Academic Research
objects.description:
A narrative makes a claim, and points to academic research to back up the legitimacy of the claim - however, the research does not actually exist.

Citation of nonexistent academic research can occur when using AI-LLMs to write reports. [AI models are trained to mimic language that humans use by predicting one word after another in a sequence. Although AI chatbots like ChatGPT often succeed in producing text that reads like it was written by a human, they often fail to ensure that what they’re saying is factual.](https://www.poynter.org/fact-checking/2025/rfk-jr-fake-citations-medical-journals/) Because of this, they may produce citations which look correct, but don’t point to research that really exists.

To count as a citation, the content must explicitly point to a specific piece of academic research to support a claim. This could be via an embedded link, footnotes, or providing the name of a paper, the journal it appears in, and the researchers who produced it.

To make this assertion, analysts must confirm that the cited research does not exist (while being lenient against honest mistakes such as slight errors in how the research is named), by investigating each citation made and confirming it exists as described.

For example, [this Fact Check](https://www.poynter.org/fact-checking/2025/rfk-jr-fake-citations-medical-journals/) looked into citations made in a report which was purportedly produced using AI:

”One of the fake articles flagged by NOTUS was titled, “Changes in mental health and substance use among US adolescents during the COVID-19 pandemic.” [...]

“A closer examination of the citation shows why it’s not authentic: Searching the title does not yield a real article, clicking the DOI link in the citation leads to an error page saying “DOI not found,” and looking at the JAMA Pediatrics volume and issue number referenced leads to an article with a different title and different authors.”

objects.name: Narrative Misrepresents Findings of Cited Academic Research
objects.description:
A narrative makes a claim, and points to academic research to back up the legitimacy of the claim - however, the research does not actually support the claim, and is misrepresented as doing so.

It could be the case that individuals make an honest mistake believing the research supports their claim. However, some actors intentionally misrepresent the findings of a cited source relying on readers not checking the source. The issue of misrepresented research also occurs when AI is used to write materials, which may confidently summarise research in a way which does not capture important nuance or details in a report.

To count as a citation, the content must explicitly point to a specific piece of academic research to support a claim. This could be via an embedded link, footnotes, or providing the name of a paper, the journal it appears in, and the researchers who produced it.

To make this assertion, analysts may contact the original author of the research and ask whether their work has been accurately characterised in the claim, or they may read the research and assess themselves how well it supports the claim.

objects.name: Narrative Cites Retracted Academic Research
objects.description:
Academic research can be retracted in cases where issues with the report are uncovered, including errors with how the research was conducted, corruption on behalf of the researchers, fake peer reviews, or publishing multiple papers based on the same data. Research such as this which has been retracted is sometimes still used to support claims, without acknowledging the results are not valid.

To count as a citation, the content must explicitly point to a specific piece of academic research to support a claim. This could be via an embedded link, footnotes, or providing the name of a paper, the journal it appears in, and the researchers who produced it.

To make this assertion, analysts need to identify the cited article, and confirm that it has been discredited. They may do this by searching for retracted academic research on publicly available databases such as (Retraction Watch,)[https://retractionwatch.com/retraction-watch-database-user-guide/] or by contacting the publishing journal.

objects.name: Narrative Cites Academic Research not Peer Reviewed
objects.description:
A narrative makes a claim, and points to academic research to back up the legitimacy of the claim - however, the research has not been peer reviewed, and this is not disclosed.

Peer review is an important part of the scientific process. It involves submitting research to other accredited experts to confirm that the researchers have conducted their investigation correctly, and following established scientific best practices (such as minimising bias, accurately reporting findings, or honesty about potential failings in research methods). Without peer review, unverified or inaccurate information could easily make its way into scientific consensus.

Some academic journals publish preliminary summaries of research (i.e. previews of results before they have been peer reviewed), which can be erroneously cited as completed research.

It is not the case that all information needs to be peer reviewed, people can share the results of research which hasn’t been peer reviewed, and this information can be valid and useful. But narratives which make claims referencing academic research which has not been peer reviewed (and do not highlight that data hasn’t been peer reviewed) can lead to the spread of misleading or incorrect information.

To count as a citation, the content must explicitly point to a specific piece of academic research to support a claim. This could be via an embedded link, footnotes, or providing the name of a paper, the journal it appears in, and the researchers who produced it.

To make this assertion, analysts need to look at the cited report, and confirm that it has not been peer reviewed.

objects.name: Issues with Presented Statistical Evidence
objects.description:
A narrative presents statistical evidence to support a claim made, but there are issues with the validity of the statistics.

This Technique contains Sub-Techniques which document specific types of statistical issues, or ways in which statistics are used.

objects.name: Narrative Presents Fabricated Statistics as Genuine Data
objects.description:
A narrative makes a claim and presents statistics that appear to be based on research or real-world data, but the numbers themselves were fabricated; they were not derived from any authentic dataset, study, or measurement process.

Common indicators include round or overly specific figures without citation (e.g., “87% of people say…”), attributions to vague or unverifiable sources (“a recent study found…”), or links that lead to unrelated or nonexistent materials. Fabricated statistics are often designed to sound plausible and authoritative, exploiting the reader’s trust in numerical evidence.

To make this assertion, analysts will need to check the source which is presented as having produced the statistics, or data used to generate the statistics, and confirm that they exist as described. Analysts may also contact the organisation or individual allegedly responsible for producing the data to confirm whether they ever published such figures.

objects.name: Narrative Uses Selective Statistics to Support Claim
objects.description:
A claim is presented alongside supporting statistics which were created using data points which were selectively counted and discounted based on whether they were beneficial to the narrative’s claim (also referred to as “cherry picking”).

Data can be discounted without counting as cherry picking; sometimes erroneous outliers skew results and need to be removed, some data points may legitimately not be valuable additions to a dataset (for example if they have been influenced by factors outside of the studied area). However, people have been observed using data selectively with the intent of producing evidence to support their claim, rather than building a claim based on unbiased evidence.

To make this assertion, analysts will need to confirm that data has been selectively chosen to support a given claim, and that it has not been discounted for legitimate reasons.

objects.name: Narrative Uses Misinterpreted Statistics to Support Claim
objects.description:
A claim is presented alongside valid statistics to back it up, but describes what those statistics mean incorrectly.

Examples of misinterpreting statistics include interpreting a statistical correlation as implying it demonstrates causation (for example, data shows that sale of ice cream correlates with higher levels of police response to aggression, but one doesn’t cause the other - a third element (summer heat) influences both), or ignoring contextual information about the data which influences its meaning (for example, data showing a sharp rise in umbrella sales used to evidence a new fashion trend, without noting that the period measured coincided with unusually heavy rainfall).

To make this assertion, analysts will need to review the original source for the statistics, and confirm that what they reveal has been misinterpreted to support a given claim. Analysts may contact the individual or organisation who produced the statistics and ask whether their work has been accurately characterised in the claim, or they may review the data themselves and assess themselves how well it supports the claim.

objects.name: Edited Content
objects.description:
This Technique can be used to assert that a piece of content has been published which was edited in some way without disclosure.

This technique’s sub-techniques provides analysts options for documenting different ways of editing content, and edits made to content.

Backwards Compatibility

In the 1.7 update to the DISARM Framework, the following Techniques were removed:

- T0086.003: Deceptively Edit Images (Cheap Fakes)
- T0087.002: Deceptively Edit Video (Cheap Fakes)
- T0088.002: Deceptively Edit Audio (Cheap Fakes)

Edits made to content should now be documented using T0165: Edited Content.

The format of content which was edited can be documented by combining T0165: Edited Content with T0085: Develop Text-Based Content, T0086: Develop Image-Based Content, T0087: Develop Video-Based Content, and T0088: Develop Audio-Based Content.

objects.name: Clipped Content
objects.description:
This sub-technique can be used to document audio or video content which is a segment taken from a longer piece of content. For example, a 20 second video which was produced by taking a short section out of a five minute video would be considered clipped content.

Actors have been observed clipping media in such a way that removes its original context, allowing for a creation of a new narrative.

To make this assessment, analysts will need to find the original unedited content, and identify the segment from which the clipped content was produced.

objects.name: Cropped Content
objects.description:
This sub-technique can be used to document Image or Video content which zooms in on a section of the original media, cropping content on the outer edges of the frame, without disclosure.

Actors have been observed cropping media in such a way that removes its original context, allowing for a creation of a new narrative. For example, a wide angle shot showing a person holding a sign at a counter-protest could be cropped to remove the sign, allowing for a new narrative that they were part of the original protest.

To make this assessment, analysts will need to find the original unedited content, and identify the section which matches the published cropped content.

objects.name: Playback Speed Altered
objects.description:
This sub-technique covers undisclosed speeding up or slowing down of Audio or Video Content prior to publication.

Actors have been observed slowing down footage of targeted speakers, making their words sound slurred, enabling narratives questioning the health of the target, or their state of mind.

To make this assessment, analysts will need to find the original unedited content, and pair sections of the published materials to sections of the original content.

objects.name: Source Edited Out of Content
objects.description:
When people publish content they created, they sometimes include ‘watermarks’ or other identifiers to help people find them if their content is reposted, and to be credited for their work. This sub-technique can be used to assert that a piece of content has been edited to remove references to the original source without disclosure.

Examples include editing videos or images to superimpose material over a watermark or logo, cropping out a watermark or logo, clipping sections of audio or video revealing the source, taking an article’s text and removing its byline.

To make this assessment, analysts will need to find the original unedited content, identify elements which help consumers of the content identify its source which do not appear in content published by the actor.

objects.name: AI-Generated Content
objects.description:
This Technique can be used to assert that a piece of content has been fully generated using AI.

This Technique’s Sub-techniques delineate specific types of AI-Generated content.

As AI continues to develop capability to produce more realistic media, it is difficult to provide a list of methods to spot materials that have been created using AI which will not rapidly become outdated; platforms providing AI media generation are attempting to make the materials they produce indistinguishable from media made by humans.

At the same time, organisations create tools designed to help identify AI-generated content, and publish resources listing the latest tells and identifiers for AI-generated content. Analysts may look for such tools or resources to help identify the use of AI.

Backwards Compatibility

In the 1.7 update to the DISARM Framework, the following Techniques were removed:

- T0085.001: Develop AI-Generated Text
- T0086.002: Develop AI-Generated Images (Deepfakes)
- T0087.001: Develop AI-Generated Videos (Deepfakes)
- T0088.001 Develop AI-Generated Audio (Deepfakes)

Content which has been AI-Generated can be documented using T0166: AI-Generated Content. Deepfakes can be documented using T0166.001: Deepfake Impersonation. The format of content which was edited can be documented using T0085: Develop Text-Based Content, T0086: Develop Image-Based Content, T0087: Develop Video-Based Content, and T0088: Develop Audio-Based Content.

objects.name: Deepfake Impersonation
objects.description:
This sub-technique can be used to assert that a piece of content is an AI-Generated deepfake impersonation.

A deepfake refers to AI-generated content that artificially inserts the likeness of a real person into a new or altered media scene. These synthetic images, videos, or audio clips use machine learning models to manipulate or replace the original content, making it appear as though the target is participating in actions or situations they never actually did.

As AI continues to develop capability to produce more realistic media, it is difficult to provide a list of methods to spot materials that have been created using AI which will not rapidly become outdated; platforms providing AI media generation are attempting to make the materials they produce indistinguishable from media made by humans.

At the same time, organisations create tools designed to help identify AI-generated content, and publish resources listing the latest tells and identifiers for AI-generated content. Analysts may look for such tools or resources to help identify the use of AI.

objects.name: Sexual Deepfake Impersonation
objects.description:
This sub-technique can be used to assert that a piece of content is a sexual AI-Generated deepfake impersonation (sometimes referred to as “AI Non-Consensual Intimate Imagery” / “AI NCII”); a deepfake which has placed a target into a sexual scene, or depicts them sexually.

A deepfake refers to AI-generated content that artificially inserts the likeness of a real person into a new or altered media scene. These synthetic images, videos, or audio clips use machine learning models to manipulate or replace the original content, making it appear as though the target is participating in actions or situations they never actually did.

To identify sexual deepfake impersonations, analysts will need to confirm that the imagery has been generated using AI, and to assert that the imagery is sexual in nature. The nature of what is considered sexual can differ based on cultural context. Analysts will need to consider the societal norms of the targeted individual, or the audience of the deepfake when asserting whether it is sexual in nature.

As AI continues to develop capability to produce more realistic media, it is difficult to provide a list of methods to spot materials that have been created using AI which will not rapidly become outdated; platforms providing AI media generation are attempting to make the materials they produce indistinguishable from media made by humans.

At the same time, organisations create tools designed to help identify AI-generated content, and publish resources listing the latest tells and identifiers for AI-generated content. Analysts may look for such tools or resources to help identify the use of AI.

objects.name: AI-Nudified Imagery
objects.description:
This sub-technique can be used to assert that AI was employed to generate AI-nudified imagery. AI-nudified imagery refers to the use of artificial intelligence to modify an existing image or video by digitally altering the subject to appear unclothed, typically through the application of machine learning algorithms that remove or replace clothing with simulated content.

Platforms designed to nudify imagery require users to upload an image of a person fully clothed as the source content. The AI then applies algorithms to remove the clothing, effectively generating a synthetic image or video of the subject in a nude state.

To make this assertion, analysts can identify the original image, and confirm that the published image has been edited using AI to appear undressed. They may use evidence such as images being submitted to AI platforms, our AI platforms identifying images they produce as nudifications.

As AI continues to develop capability to produce more realistic media, it is difficult to provide a list of methods to spot materials that have been created using AI which will not rapidly become outdated; platforms providing AI media generation are attempting to make the materials they produce indistinguishable from media made by humans.

At the same time, organisations create tools designed to help identify AI-generated content, and publish resources listing the latest tells and identifiers for AI-generated content. Analysts may look for such tools or resources to help identify the use of AI.

objects.name: Issue with Content's Headline
objects.description:
This Technique contains Sub-Techniques which allow analysts to identify issues with how a piece of content has been titled.

Users of social media platforms often do not click in to view online content, and as such commonly only see its’ headline, where effectively experience the headline of the article as the whole article. In cases where a screenshot of a headline is posted, users are unable to view the rest of the content for context. Because of this, issues with content’s headlines can easily mislead people online.

objects.name: Use of Clickbait
objects.description:
“Clickbait” is defined as “(online content that is specifically designed to entice a reader to click on a link, but which offers very little reward for doing so)[https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0378216621000229?via%3Dihub]”. (These are sensationalist and hyperbolic headlines which often use a formulaic structure, vocabulary, and style. These headlines entice readers to click by creating an information gap. They imply that some relevant information exists, and they indicate that the readers will gain access to that information if they click through and read the article.)[https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378216623002643#bib4:~:text=These%20are%20sensationalist,read%20the%20article] In contrast, (headlines in traditional news media tend not to leave information gaps, but rather, they provide a summary of the associated story.)[https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378216623002643#bib4:~:text=headlines%20in%20traditional%20news%20media%20tend%20not%20to%20leave%20information%20gaps%2C%20but%20rather%2C%20they%20provide%20a%20summary%20of%20the%20associated%20story]

Examples of different types of Clickbait include:

Curiosity-gap headlines: Withholding key information so readers feel compelled to click (e.g., “You Won’t Believe What Scientists Found…”).
Outrage or shock-bait: Framing something in an emotionally charged or polarizing way to provoke anger or disbelief. (“When She Walked In, He Did WHAT?!”)
Sensationalized exaggeration: Inflating significance, stakes, or novelty (“This Simple Trick Will Change Your Life Forever”).
Bait-and-switch imagery: Using a thumbnail or image that suggests content not actually present in the article.
Celebrity or authority clickbait: Implying endorsement, conflict, or scandal involving public figures (“Elon Musk Just Said This About Teachers”).
Fear-based clickbait: Leveraging risk or danger (“Your Phone Could Be Spying on You Right Now; Here’s What You Need to Do”).
Fake scarcity or urgency: Creating a false sense of time pressure (“Don’t Get Caught Out: New Law Will Impact EVERYONE”).
Emotional heartstring-bait: Overplaying sentimentality (“What They Saw Will Make You Cry”).

Clickbait doesn’t necessarily have to require a clickthrough to view content; it can also be used to encourage sharing or interacting with posts made to social media platforms. For example, posts which falsely claim celebrity deaths have been published to garner interactions with a page’s content, without linking out to an associated article.

The use of clickbait is not by itself indicative of malicious behaviour, news outlets often require users to click on an article to be paid for their journalism. However, actors have been observed producing low quality or outright false content while using clickbait headlines to increase the likelihood that it is viewed by a target audience.

Backwards Compatibility

In the 1.7 update to the DISARM Framework, the following Technique was removed:

T0016: Create Clickbait

This was replaced by T0167.001: Use of Clickbait.

objects.name: Title Misrepresents Content
objects.description:
Titles or headlines which do not accurately reflect what is contained in a piece of content. This is sometimes referred to as “(deceptive clickbait)[https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378216623002643#bib4:~:text=%E2%80%9Cdeceptive%E2%80%9D%20clickbait.]”, It differs from clickbait in that instead of creating a knowledge gap to induce clicking, they create a headline which tells a ‘full story’ but leads to an interpretation which misrepresents the material’s contents in such a way that makes the reader believe its material is highly relevant or interesting to them.

Users of social media platforms often do not click in to view online content, and as such commonly only see its’ title, where effectively experience the headline of a piece of content as the whole content. In cases where a screenshot of a title is posted, users are unable to view the rest of the content for context. Titles which misrepresent content can then mislead people into believing false information.

Fact Checkers have observed cases where viral information could be debunked simply by checking the article (common for headlines produced by satirical media outlets).

To make this assertion, analysts will need to review the article or video and make the assessment as to whether its title accurately reflects its content.

objects.name: Collaborating Assets Seed and Ping
objects.description:
The “Seed and Ping” (also known as “Seed and Quote”) strategy involves two assets on a social platform (typically accounts, likely controlled by the same actor), in which one of the assets posts content, and the other asset quotes their post, tagging a target individual or institution in the quote post.

Actors have been observed using this Technique to draw Influencers’, News Outlets’, and Fact Checkers’ attention to campaign content, in what appears to be an attempt to amplify their narratives through existing assets with large followings, or (in the case of News Outlets and Fact Checkers) to overwhelm their investigative resources.

Collaborating assets will switch their role between Seeder and Pinger over time. Per Viginum’s report on (Matryoshka; A pro-Russian campaign targeting media and the fact-checking community:)[https://www.sgdsn.gouv.fr/files/files/20240611_NP_SGDSN_VIGINUM_Matriochka_EN_VF.pdf]

“X accounts involved in the Matryoshka campaign are used to conduct several successive operations, a quoter’s account almost systematically becoming a seeder’s account and vice versa. For example, @wosuhitsu1972 was involved in at least five Matryoshka operations from 14 to 28 March 2024, in turn as a quoter, a seeder, a seeder, a quoter then a seeder.”

Quoting another account’s post and tagging another individual is not by itself indicative of the Seed and Ping strategy; many people will legitimately encounter content which they would like to draw to the attention of influencers, or to ask for material to be verified by journalists.

To make the assessment that assets are collaborating to use a Seed and Ping strategy, analysts need to confirm that assets do not disclose an association with each other, and yet have repeatedly interacted by quoting each others’ posts and tagging another unrelated asset asking them to review the posted content.

Since assets switch role of Seeder and Pinger, analysts may observe this switch as an indicator of collaboration. They may also look for assets collaborating outside of a pair - it could be many assets collaborating to Seed and Ping each other (i.e. it’s not the case that two assets always switch between Seeding and Pinging for each other).

objects.name: Solicit Production of Fact Check
objects.description:
An asset has asked another asset to check the veracity of a claim or content published online.

While it’s natural and desired for users who authentically encounter claims or content they are unsure about to ask for support checking their veracity, threat actors have been observed posting campaign content with one asset, and using another to ask media organisations to confirm the content’s veracity (with the presumed objective of boosting its visibility, or tying up the organisation’s resources).

To make this assertion, analysts need to observe an asset (e.g. an account, a page) requesting another asset (usually a fact checking organisation, news outlet, or other media organisation) to confirm the veracity of something they have seen. This could be a claim or piece of content they provide, or a link to another source which hosts a claim or content.

This Technique by itself is not indicative of malicious behaviour, but can help understand campaign actions or objectives when observed in assets attributed to a threat actor.

objects.name: Compromised Persona
objects.description:
Assets which legitimately belong to individuals or institutions with established personas can be compromised (i.e. hacked, or otherwise taken over) and controlled by an actor. The actor can take actions with the asset while maintaining the established persona - effectively presenting the actions as having been taken by the asset’s original owner.

This Sub-Technique is used to document actions taken by threat actors while in control of a compromised asset, and maintaining the persona of the original asset owner’s persona.

For example, a celebrity’s account could be hacked, and made to post a bitcoin scam, taking advantage of their followers’ faith in the celebrity, and their knowledge that the account legitimately belongs to them (even though, unawares to them, the celebrity is not in control of the asset at that moment - their persona has been compromised).

objects.name: Voyeuristic Content
objects.description:
Voyeuristic Content is defined as (image or video content secretively taken of another individual for a sexual purpose.)[https://www.cigionline.org/publications/technology-facilitated-gender-based-violence-overview/]

Voyeuristic Content is typically produced using hidden cameras, or discreet photography Observations; using a zoom lens, or taking a photo when the target is not paying attention.

Actors have been observed attempting to produce Voyeuristic Content targeting women by taking photos up their skirts (called “Upskirting”) or down their tops (“Downblousing”) without their knowledge or consent. Actors also secretively photograph women from afar for sexual gratification (“Creepshots”).

Analysts will need to make an assessment about whether content was produced for sexual gratification, and whether the depicted individual was aware they were being filmed. Analysts may use context of the platform or community the content was posted to, or how it was described by the actor, to make such an assessment.

objects.name: Unsolicited Sexual Imagery
objects.description:
Unsolicited Sexual Imagery (sometimes referred to as “cyberflashing”, or colloquially as a “dick pic”) is defined as image or video content showing (“a person’s genitals, for the purpose of their own sexual gratification or to cause the victim humiliation, alarm or distress”)[https://www.gov.uk/government/news/cyberflashing-to-become-a-criminal-offence]. Unsolicited sexual imagery is a form of harassment often targeting women online.

Analysts may use context of the community or individual the content was posted to, how it was described by the actor, or prior communication from the recipient, to make such an assessment.

objects.name: Unsolicited Request for Sexual Imagery
objects.description:
An Unsolicited Request for Sexual Imagery is defined as any content which contains a request for the target to produce and deliver sexual imagery of themselves, colloquially referred to as ‘nudes’. Unsolicited requests for sexual imagery is a form of harassment often targeting women online.

Analysts may use context of the community or individual the content was posted to, how it was described by the actor, or prior communication from the recipient, to make such an assessment.

objects.name: Non-Consensual Publication of Private Intimate Imagery
objects.description:
Private Intimate Imagery depicts an individual in a state of undress, engaging in sexual activity, or in other intimate situations where there is a reasonable expectation of privacy. This imagery is typically created or shared with the subject’s consent for private use.

Non-consensual publication of private intimate imagery involves sharing the imagery outside of its original intended audience without consent of the depicted individuals.

Analysts may use context of the platform or community the content was posted to, or how it was described by the actor, to make an assessment that private intimate imagery has been published to another audience non-consensually.

objects.name: Threaten Physical Violence
objects.description:
Content qualifies as a threat of physical violence when it communicates, implicitly or explicitly, the intent to cause bodily harm to a specific individual. Threat actors may use such threats to coerce targets into taking or avoiding certain actions by invoking credible offline harm.

Analysts should confirm that the published content could reasonably be interpreted as a physical threat by its intended recipient.

objects.name: Threaten Physical Sexual Violence
objects.description:
Content qualifies as a threat of physical sexual violence when it communicates, implicitly or explicitly, an intention to inflict sexual harm or coerced sexual acts on a specific individual. Threat actors may use such threats to intimidate or compel targets into taking or avoiding certain actions by invoking credible offline sexual harm. Threats of physical sexual violence is a form of harassment often targeting women online.

Analysts should confirm that the published content could reasonably be interpreted as a threat of sexual violence by its intended recipient.

objects.name: Content Depicting Physical Sexual Violence
objects.description:
Content qualifies as depicting physical sexual violence when posted or streamed material shows, suggests, or meaningfully represents non-consensual sexual acts or sexual harm involving real individuals.

Publishing such material can revictimise survivors by re-exposing them to the assault, enabling further circulation, and amplifying the emotional, psychological, and social impact of the violence.

Analysts should determine that the content clearly portrays physical sexual violence, assess whether consent is absent or impossible.

objects.name: Sextortion
objects.description:
(“Sexual extortion, or “sextortion,” occurs when an individual has, or claims to have, a sexual image of another person and uses it to coerce a person into doing something they do not want to do”.)[https://www.cigionline.org/static/documents/SaferInternet_Paper_no_1_coverupdate.pdf]

To make this assessment, analysts must confirm that messaging threatens the non-consensual publication of sexual content depicting the target, with a demand for some kind of action.

objects.name: Send Message
objects.description:
Some platforms or platforms’ features enable users to send messages. Direct or Group messaging mimics the flow of conversation between two or more users, showing the most recent message sent by anyone participating in the conversation.

On platforms such as Discord, WhatsApp, and Telegram are primarily interacted with by sending messages (T0115.004: Send Message), although some (such as Slack) also support creating posts (T0115: Post Content).

Many online platforms support sending messages in group chats (T0151.006: Chat Room) or via direct message (T0153.007: Direct Messaging).

Email providers such as Gmail, iCloud mail, and Microsoft Outlook (T0153.001: Email Platform) allow users to send messages to accounts on any email platform.

objects.name: Rhetorical Device
objects.description:
Rhetoric is the study of writing or speaking as a means of communication or persuasion. Rhetorical devices are used to make an argument more persuasive or appealing to an audience.

Rhetorical devices are not inherently malicious; people naturally use many in their day-to-day lives, talking to friends, family, and colleagues. However, they can be used with intent to manipulate, to push a particular point, to persuade targets to believe a certain way, and analysts have noted that some actors regularly deploy the same rhetorical devices (e.g. Russian actors have been observed using Whataboutism).

It can be useful to document the different rhetorical devices used in operations to influence targets.

objects.name: Narrative Uses False Cause
objects.description:
False cause is a logical fallacy in which a cause-and-effect relationship is asserted without sufficient evidence. It occurs when someone assumes that because two events are correlated, or one follows the other, the first must have caused the second. This reasoning ignores other possible explanations, such as coincidence, external factors, or reverse causation.

For example, the sale of ice cream correlates with higher levels of police response to aggression, but one doesn’t cause the other - a third element (summer heat) influences both.

While correlations can suggest possible links, treating them as proof of causality leads to flawed conclusions and can easily misinform public debate, science, or policy decisions.

To make this assertion, analysts should look for claims which point to two or more co-occurring events and state that one causes the others, without providing evidence (e.g. scientific research, or statistics).

objects.name: Narrative Uses Whataboutism
objects.description:
“Whataboutism” is a method of deflecting criticism or other substantive point by using a “What about …” style response; instead of authentically engaging with and addressing the issue, attempting to shift focus, create false equivalence, or undermine the opponent’s position without offering a genuine rebuttal.

Whataboutism is not always deployed as a form of manipulation; sometimes it is authentically used with the objective of pointing out the injustice of hypocritical accusations, or the lack of moral position an accuser has. Issues used to deploy Whataboutism are often legitimate problems which should also be resolved.

However we know that Whataboutism is employed by people who aren’t really worried about the issue they raise; they just want to deflect, and move on the topic of discussion.

[This report provides an example of Whataboutism:](https://theconversation.com/whataboutism-what-it-is-and-why-its-such-a-popular-tactic-in-arguments-182911)

“As bickering couples and parents of siblings will know, [Whataboutism] happens in daily life all too often. “You lied about where you were last night!” a person feeling wronged will say. To which, instead of owning up, the partner replies: “Well, what about you? You lie to me all the time!””

Here, the individual uses Whataboutism to deflect from the accusation they lied about where they were last night.

To make the assertion that a narrative is using Whataboutism, analysts should look for cases where an individual or institution is facing a claim or accusation and, instead of addressing the claim, they deflect by raising another issue.

objects.name: Narrative Uses Cherry Picking
objects.description:
Cherry-picking is a misleading argumentative strategy that involves focusing only on data, quotes, or examples that reinforce a specific thesis, while omitting information that provides context or contradicts the desired conclusion. By isolating favorable evidence and disregarding the broader picture, the speaker creates a distorted impression of the truth.

To make the assertion that a narrative is using cherry picking it must be evident that the surrounding data or evidence around an assertion must in some way contradict or alters the meaning that the narrative is trying to convey. Further it helps if the additional data or evidence is not far removed from the data or evidence reported by the narrative.

objects.name: Narrative Uses Anecdote
objects.description:
The use of evidence in the form of personal experience or an isolated case, possibly rumour or hearsay, most often to discredit large study findings or statistics. Anecdotal evidence is not credible because it is based on a small sample size (often one person), there is a lack of control (unlike in a controlled experiment), we don’t have causation so we don’t know if the variable in question is the cause of the effect we’re looking at.

To make the assertion that a narrative is using an anecdote they must have a very small sample size (typically one person), it is not from a controlled setting, and we must not have direct proven causation.

objects.name: Narrative Uses Strawman
objects.description:
The Strawman (or “Straw Men” / “Straw Man”) fallacy occurs when an opponent’s argument is distorted or oversimplified so that it can be easily dismissed. Instead of engaging with the actual position being presented, the speaker replaces it with a weaker, often caricatured version (the “strawman”) and then proceeds to argue against that. This tactic gives the illusion of having successfully countered an argument, when in reality the true point was never addressed.

For example, if somebody suggested “We should consider reducing car traffic in the city center on weekends to ease congestion”, and another replied “So you want to ban all cars and make it impossible for people to get around?”, this would be a Strawman - misrepresenting the original argument, making it appear more extreme and easier to dispute.

Note that a Strawman doesn’t necessarily need to be made in response to an argument. Actors may use a Strawman to create extreme or illogical positions held by people with opposing political views, and argue against such positions. This can also include cases when positions are attributed to individuals who never held such a position.

To identify Strawman, analysts should look for cases where someone responds to a position by rephrasing it into a weaker, exaggerated, or different claim and then attacking that distorted version instead of the original. Indicators include oversimplifying a nuanced argument, attributing absolute or extreme views which weren’t expressed, or ignoring key qualifications. If the rebuttal seems aimed at a version of the argument which was never actually made, it is likely a Strawman.

objects.name: Narrative Uses Leading Question
objects.description:
Leading questions are a manipulative questioning technique where the phrasing or sequence of questions subtly steers the respondent toward a predetermined conclusion. Instead of neutrally seeking information, the questioner embeds assumptions, implications, or emotional cues that make certain answers seem more acceptable or obvious.

To make the assertion that a narrative is using leading questions can be based on several rhetorical methods: bias present in the words (eg. saying “smashed” instead of “hit”), use of assumptions that are inbuilt (eg. when did you stop stealing roadsigns) or the use of a tag at the end to solicit agreement (eg. you did eat all of my pancakes, didn’t you?). Many leading questions can be answered through a yes or a no answer (eg. my pancakes were delicious, weren’t they?).

objects.name: Narrative Uses Appeal to Emotion
objects.description:
Appeal to emotion is a rhetorical strategy where the speaker relies on emotional manipulation rather than rational argument to influence an audience’s attitude or decision. By using words, imagery, or tone designed to evoke feelings such as fear, anger, pride, pity, or outrage, the communicator steers the listener toward a desired conclusion without addressing the actual merits of the issue.

To make the assertion that a narrative is using an appeal to emotion can be highly subjective. It is best to identify which emotion is being manipulated and how far from neutral communication the narrative is.

objects.name: Narrative Uses Exaggeration
objects.description:
Exaggeration is a rhetorical technique that involves intentionally stretching the truth or emphasizing certain aspects of a situation beyond their actual proportions. It can serve as a persuasive, emotional, or stylistic device (for example, to dramatize a point, evoke strong reactions, or draw attention to an issue).

While exaggeration can be used playfully or for emphasis, in argumentation it often leads to distortion by misrepresenting reality or misleading an audience.

To make the assertion that a narrative is using exaggeration, analysts should look for language that amplifies reality beyond reasonable limits, for instance, claims that use absolute terms (“always,” “everyone,” “the worst ever”), vivid overstatements, or emotionally charged descriptions that make an issue seem far more extreme than evidence supports. Such cues often appear in opinion writing, political rhetoric, or advertising, where emotional appeal is prioritized over factual accuracy. To substantiate the claim, one should compare the narrative’s description of events, numbers, or consequences with credible data or context; if the depiction consistently heightens intensity, danger, or significance without proportionate evidence, it can be reasonably identified as exaggeration.

objects.name: DISARM Foundation
objects.description: DISARM is a framework designed for describing and understanding disinformation incidents.

objects.name: DISARM V2 Observations Framework
objects.description: The DISARM V2 Observations Framework standardizes the descriptions of observations made by analysts which pertain to suspected adversary operations or campaigns.
